questions.text: What are the differentiating features of psoriatic arthritis from RA?
questions.solution:
• Pencil-in-cup deformity and telescoping of phalanges are hallmark features of psoriatic arthritis, not seen in RA.
  • Marginal erosions appear in both PsA and RA. But in PsA, they're accompanied by periostitis and bone proliferation, while RA tends to show symmetric erosions and more osteoporosis.

Psoriatic arthritis:

  • Psoriatic Arthropathy presents as a polyarthritis, where the distal IP joints of hands are commonly involved (unlike rheumatoid arthritis, where these are spared)
  • RA factor is negative.
  • Males and Females are equally affected.
  • There is a strong genetic predisposition; a family history of psoriasis is often present, and almost 60% of patients who have a concomitant sacroiliitis or spondylitis lesion are positive for HLA-B27.
  • The HLA-Cw6 gene is also associated with the disorder.
  • Classic skin lesions and nail lesions help in the diagnosis
  • The patient may present with one of several patterns of joint involvement (described by Wright and Mall)
    1. Arthritis of DIP joints
    2. Asymmetrical oligoarthritis: most common pattern
    3. Symmetrical polyarthritis similar to RA
    4. Axial involvement similar to ankylosing spondylitis
    5. Arthritis mutilans where there is extensive destruction of finger joints

Clinical features:

  • The hand may develop telescoping of IP joints, which is called Opera glass digits.
  • Swelling of fingers can result in sausage digits.
  • X-ray of the hand shows pencil-in-cup deformity.

Treatment:

  • The drug of choice for psoriatic arthritis-Methotrexate
  • Treatment is by methotrexate, anti-TNF agents (Etanercept and infliximab), and steroids.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seronegative arthritis?
questions.solution:
Arthritis can be of 2 types:

  • Seropositive arthritis-RA
  • Seronegative arthritis:
    • Noninflammatory arthritis-Osteoarthritis, hypothyroidism
    • Inflammatory arthritis:
      • Ankylosing spondylitis (AS)
      • Psoriatic arthritis (PsA)
      • Reactive arthritis
      • Arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel disorders (enteropathic arthritis) and
      • Undifferentiated SpA

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with an acute onset of pain in his left great toe. X-ray of the left foot shows punched-out lesions with overhanging margins on the 1st metatarsal head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• G sign/Martel sign: Punched out lesion of bone with overhanging bony edges. This is seen in the Gout.

Gout:

  • It is a disorder of purine metabolism characterised by hyperuricemia (uric acid >7 mg/dL) that leads to the deposition of monosodium urate crystals in joints and periarticular tissues and thereby precipitates recurrent attacks of acute synovitis and eventually leads to arthritis
  • The hyperuricemia in gout may be due to:
    • Underexcretion of uric acid (90%)
    • Overproduction of uric acid (10%)
  • Factors predisposing to gout:
    • Obese, alcoholic middle-aged (usually over 30 years) male patient
    • Dietary excess of purine-rich foods: Meat, beans, peas, cauliflower, lentils, spinach, mushrooms, alcohol.
    • Trauma, post-surgery
  • The pathogenesis of gout is the high body total urate levels that cause the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (called as tophi) into the synovium of joints.
  • Acute gout: It is characterized by sudden onset, severe joint pain with red, hot, swollen, shiny overlying skin that mimics septic arthritis. The most common site of involvement is the MTP joint of the great toe (podagra)
  • Chronic gout: Recurrent acute attacks in due course lead to chronic gout. It is asymmetric and polyarticular. Joints become eroded, painful and eventually stiff and deformed.
  • X-ray changes include:
    • Soft tissue swelling (may be the only sign during acute attack)
    • Periarticular deep erosions - Rat/flea-bitten appearance
    • Joint space narrowing
    • G sign/Martel sign - Punched out lesion of bone with overhanging bony edges.

Treatment:

  • Drugs used in acute gout- NSAIDs (drug of choice), colchicine (fastest acting drug), corticosteroids
  • Drugs used in chronic gout: Allopurinol (drug of choice), probenecid, sulfinpyrazone

Explanation of other options:

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA)(Option A): Causes marginal erosions and joint-space narrowing, but does not produce overhanging margins. Erosions in RA are typically more uniform, without sclerotic rims or rat-bite appearance.

Reiter's disease (Reactive Arthritis)(Option B): May show enthesitis and periostitis, but lacks punched-out erosions with overhanging margins.

Psoriatic arthritis(Option C): Features like "pencil-in-cup" deformities and periostitis can be seen, but GREATER ray erosions with overhanging edges are more characteristic of gout.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents to the OPD with pain in several joints of the hand. On examination, there are features of arthritis in PIP, DIP and 1st CMC joint. However, the wrist is spared. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Osteoarthritis:

  • Osteoarthritis (OA) is a chronic, age-related degenerative disorder of joints in which there is progressive softening and destruction of articular cartilage accompanied by new growth of bone at the joint margins (osteophytes), cyst formation in the subchondral area, sclerosis in the subchondral bone, mild synovitis and capsular fibrosis.
  • The term osteoarthritis is a misnomer. There is no inflammation of any particular structure in osteoarthritis. It is purely a degenerative condition.

In OA of the hand, classic involvement includes:

  • DIP joints (Heberden's nodes)
  • PIP joints (Bouchard's nodes)
  • 1st CMC joint (thumb base)
  • The wrist is typically spared

Psoriatic arthritis (Option C) can involve DIPs, PIPs, and wrists, and is often asymmetric and includes nail/skin features, less likely given the wrist sparing.

Gout (Option D) typically presents with acute, monoarticular attacks and tophi-not multiple chronic joint involvement as described.

Key takeaways:

The most common joint involved in various pathologies:

  • Septic arthritis - Knee joint
  • Gout - MP joint of the great toe
  • Pseudo gout - Knee joint
  • Rheumatoid arthritis - Metacarpophalangeal joint
  • Ankylosing spondylitis - Sacroiliac joint
  • Osteoarthritis - Knee joint> Hip joint
  • Senile osteoporosis - Vertebrae
  • Paget's disease - Pelvic bone > Femur > Vertebrae
  • Osteochondritis dissecans Knee joint

questions.text: You are asked to see a 70-year-old woman with a swollen right knee that is warm and tender. You perform an arthrocentesis and observe positively birefringent, rhomboid-shaped crystals on polarized microscopy. The gram stain shows no organisms, and the synovial fluid culture grows no organisms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Pseudogout is caused by calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals, which are positively birefringent on polarized microscopy.
  • Pseudogout most commonly affects the knee and, unlike gout, is more common in women than men. Polyarticular gout and pseudogout may mimic rheumatoid arthritis.
  • The lack of symmetry, prolonged morning stiffness, positive serologies, and systemic symptoms may help differentiate polyarticular crystal arthropathy from rheumatoid arthritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of osteoarthritis of the knee joint?
questions.solution:
• Radiological features of osteoarthritis:
    • Joint space reduction (due to loss of cartilage)
    • Osteophytes formation
    • Subchondral sclerosis (due to condensation of trabeculae)
    • Subchondral cyst formation (due to osteonecrosis and seeping of synovial fluid into cracks)

choices.text: TB arthritis of hip joint in adult
TB arthritis of the hip joint in infancy
Septic arthritis of the hip in infancy
TB arthritis of knee joint in infancy

questions.solution:
Tom Smith arthritis:

  • Tom Smith arthritis is the septic arthritis of the hip in infants. It is rapidly progressive and can cause extensive destruction of an infant's hip.
  • In a child of less than 1 year of age, the head of the femur is cartilaginous which gets easily and rapidly destroyed by the bacteria. A child with advanced Tom Smith arthritis will lose the entire femoral head and the child will have an unstable hip for the rest of his/ her life resulting in a lifelong limp.
  • On examination, the child walks with a limp, there is a shortening of the affected limb with the attitude of external rotation, and the range of motion of the hip is increased in all directions.
  • The Telescope test at the hip is positive.

Treatment:

  • Urgent arthroscopy and lavage of the hip joint must be done to save the hip. Empirical antibiotics are started after surgery and definitive antibiotics are started after culture and sensitivity reportsbecome available.

questions.text: Bunion is commonly seen at which of the following areas?
questions.solution:
• A bunion, also known as hallux valgus, is a deformity of the MTP joint. The big toe often bends towards the other toes and the joint becomes red and painful. The onset of bunions is typically gradual. Complications may include bursitis or arthritis.

Causes:

  • Proposed factors include wearing overly tight shoes, high-heeled shoes, family history and rheumatoid arthritis.

Symptoms:

  • Include irritation of the skin around the bunion, and blisters may form more easily at the site. Pain may be worse when walking.

Treatment:

  • Includes corrective splints and deformity corrective surgery

questions.text: A 30-year-old male comes to your clinic complaining of red and itchy eyes for the last 12 hrs. When asked for their past history, he recalls going to the emergency department 2 months ago for diarrhea. The patient also had diffuse joint pains and pain on urination for one month. He has tested negative for RA factor but is HLA B27 positive. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Conjunctivitis with a history of urethritis and diarrhoea is suggestive of Reactive arthritis. Most patients are between 20 to 30 years old with HLA B27 positive.
  • Reactive arthritis is thought to be caused by an autoimmune reaction to genitourinary or gastrointestinal infection.
  • Two forms are recognized: a dysenteric form and a sexually transmitted form.
  • The former occurs with infection after the Shigella, Salmonella and Campylobacter species while the latter is seen in cases of urogenital tract infections with Chlamydia trachomatis, Mycoplasma genitalium or Lymphogranuloma venereum.
  • Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of reactive arthritis
  • Reiter's syndrome is a clinical triad of non-erosive reactive arthritis, urethritis and conjunctivitis
  • The usual age of onset is 20-40 years with men being affected more commonly than women (10:1).
  • X-rays usually show features of non-erosive arthritis of affected joints.
  • Most patients can be managed with symptomatic treatment with NSAIDs.

Explanation of other options:

  • Ankylosing spondylitis(Option A): is a chronic progressive inflammatory seronegative spondyloarthropathy, present with back pain and stiffness associated with uveitis and aortic regurgitation.it is strongly associated with HLA B27allele.
  • Lyme arthritis(Option B): usually caused by a bite from a tick harbouring the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi, presents with local skin rash, arthritis and arthralgia.
  • Psoriatic arthritis(Option D): The patient presents with skin and nail lesions along with arthritis.

Osteochondrosis/Epiphysitis:

  • Osteochondrosis includes a group of conditions that are disorders of the growing epiphysis and hence also called as epiphysitis. Technically, it refers to inflammation of the osteochondral (bone-cartilage junction) part of the joint.
  • As per the probable aetiology, the lesion in different locations is named differently:
  • Crushing Type (occurring due to increased intraosseous pressure):
    • Freiberg's disease: Metatarsal heads
    • Kohler's disease: Navicular
    • Kienbock's disease: Lunate
    • Panner's disease: Capitulum
    • Scheuermann's disease: Ring epiphysis of vertebrae
    • Calve's disease: Central bony nucleus of vertebrae.
    • Theeman's disease: Phalangeal epiphysis.
  • Traction/Pulling Type (occurring at places with traction epiphysis):
    • Tibial tuberosity: Osgood-Schlatter's disease
    • Calcaneal epiphysis: Sever's disease
    • Patellar ligament (at its lower pole patellar attachment): Johanssen-Larsen syndrome
    • The base of the 5th metatarsal: Iselin's disease.
    • Medial epicondyle of the humerus: Adam's disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of neuropathic joints?
questions.solution:
Neuropathic Joint:

  • It is a progressive destructive (but painless) arthritis that arises from loss of pain and proprioceptive joint sensations.
  • Clinically, the joint manifests as painless effusion, deformity, or instability.
  • The X-ray changes are those of severe osteoarthritis, but without many clinical findings like pain, muscle spasms, etc.
  • Treatment is difficult. Bracing is usually advised for some joints. Charcot-resistant orthotic walker (CROW) is the most common brace used for Charcot joints of the foot and ankle.
